thread.title: Circulator Banner Route gets funding lifeline
thread.title_full: Circulator Banner Route gets funding lifeline

author: Ryan Sharrow
title: Circulator Banner Route gets funding lifeline
text:
See All Homes of the Day Howard Libit , a spokesman for Rawlings-Blake, said the fiscal year 2016 funding for the Banner Route will come from $2.9 million that had been earmarked for debt retirement on the circulator and for the replacement of circulator vehicles. Those actions have now been deferred to future years. Rawlings-Blake announced the savor of the Banner Route at a public event at the Baltimore Museum of Industry. Councilman Eric Costello , who represents South Baltimore, had been a strong supporter of maintaining the Banner Route and joined the mayor at the event. Businesses located along the Banner Route, including Under Armour Inc., had called on city officials to rethink eliminating the service. Libit said Rawlings-Blake directed the city's finance department to take a deeper look at finding the funds to support the Banner Route after Gov. Larry Hogan announced the state would not help finance the $2.9 billion Red Line light rail extension. Libit said Rawlings-Blake plans to press the Hogan administration to study the existing Maryland Transit Administration bus lines along circulator routes to help determine ways to fill transit gaps the circulator is currently filling.
